person.persName: Luke P. Blackburn (New Orleans/ Mississippi/ Canada)

body.p: Born June 16, 1816 in Woodford County, Kentucky. Blackburn graduated from Transylvania University in Lexington, Kentucky in 1835 with his medical degree. After graduation, Blackburn set up a practice in Lexington, Kentucky. In 1843, he was elected to the Kentucky House of Representatives and served a single term. In 1844, he established a practice in Frankfort, Kentucky. In 1847, He and his wife, Ella Boswell, moved to Natchez, Mississippi. In 1858, Blackburn established a practice in New Orleans, Louisiana. In 1861, Blackburn served as envoy for Governor Magoffin to New Orleans to procure arms and ammunition for the Confederate defense of Kentucky. He failed in this mission and was only able to send back a fraction of what was requested. Blackburn then became the aide-de-camp for Sterling Price in Mississippi. In 1863, Mississippi governor John J. Pettus appointed him to relocate the military wounded in the state. In August 1863, Blackburn and his wife traveled to Canada to procure items to be smuggled into the Confederacy through the blockade. He was accused of smuggling At the end of the war, he was accused of attempting to creating a Yellow Fever epidemic in the North by a Confederate double agent. This accusation was never proven. Died September 14, 1887 in Frankfort, Franklin County, Kentucky.
